latest news.eng_title: NASA explains decision to return Boeing Starliner without astronauts
latest news.summary: NASA officials have announced that the Boeing Starliner spacecraft will return to Earth without a crew aboard, citing safety concerns. The spacecraft, which carried astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams to the International Space Station on June 5, has experienced several issues, including helium leaks and problems with its reaction control thrusters. NASA has determined that the strange sound the spacecraft made while attached to the space station was an audio feedback issue within the communications system. Wilmore and Williams will remain on the space station and return home in February 2025 aboard the SpaceX Dragon spacecraft. The uncrewed Boeing Starliner is expected to depart from the space station at 6:04 p.m. EDT on Friday, September 6, and land at White Sands Space Harbor in New Mexico at 12:03 a.m. on Saturday, September 7.
latest news.title: NASA explains decision to return Boeing Starliner without astronauts

latest news.eng_title: Why are astronauts stuck in space? Starliner to head home
latest news.summary: Boeing's Starliner space capsule will return to Earth on Friday without its crew, Sunita 'Suni' Williams and Barry 'Butch' Wilmore, who will stay on the International Space Station until February. The capsule will undock from the space station at 6:04 p.m. Eastern time and land at the White Sands Space Harbor in New Mexico using parachutes and airbags. NASA says the two astronauts are not 'stuck' or 'stranded' as the space station has room and supplies to accommodate them. They will return home on the SpaceX Crew-9 capsule, scheduled for liftoff on September 24. This is the third uncrewed flight of the Starliner capsule, which has already completed two successful landings in December 2019 and May 2022.
latest news.title: Why are astronauts stuck in space? Starliner to head home

latest news.eng_title: Boeing Starliner Return: Sunita Williams And Butch Wilmore Prepare Spacecraft For Uncrewed Journey Back To Earth - Boeing (NYSE:BA)
latest news.summary: The crew aboard the International Space Station prepared Boeing's Starliner spacecraft for its uncrewed departure later this week, NASA said. Sunita Williams and Butch Wilmore reconfigured the spacecraft's seats for an uncrewed landing and packed cargo inside it meant to reach back Earth. The two astronauts were originally supposed to return on the Starliner, but technical issues delayed their return journey. They will now return with Crew-9 astronauts in February. The Starliner is now slated to undock from the space station on September 6 and land at White Sands Space Harbor in New Mexico at about 12:03 a.m. on September 7.
latest news.title: Boeing Starliner Return: Sunita Williams And Butch Wilmore Prepare Spacecraft For Uncrewed Journey Back To Earth - Boeing (NYSE:BA)

latest news.eng_title: Troubled Boeing Starliner will return empty on flight set for Friday
latest news.summary: The Boeing Starliner space capsule, which has been plagued by issues, will return to Earth without a crew on a flight scheduled for Friday evening. NASA Administrator Bill Nelson said, 'Spaceflight is risky, even at its safest and most routine... The decision to keep Butch and Suni aboard the International Space Station and bring Boeing's Starliner home uncrewed is the result of our commitment to safety: our core value and our North Star.' The Starliner was originally planned to return with astronauts Suni Williams and Butch Wilmore, but NASA decided to keep them on the ISS due to ongoing uncertainty and a lack of concurrence among engineers and experts. The spacecraft has experienced issues with its maneuvering thrusters and helium leaks, and NASA has been working with Boeing to update its systems for the autonomous return flight. The Starliner is designed for pilotless flight and has completed two uncrewed test flights previously. NASA will provide live coverage of the return with streaming connections available on NASA+, the NASA app, and the agency's website.
latest news.title: Troubled Boeing Starliner will return empty on flight set for Friday

latest news.eng_title: NASA astronauts awaits 2025 SpaceX ride home: Starliner to return to Earth without Sunita Williams; here's how to watch
latest news.summary: The Boeing Starliner spacecraft, carrying NASA astronauts Butch Wilmore and Sunita Williams, encountered technical issues during its first crewed mission. Due to safety concerns, NASA decided to return the spacecraft to Earth without its crew. The astronauts will now return to Earth in February 2025 aboard a SpaceX Dragon spacecraft. Meanwhile, the uncrewed Starliner spacecraft will complete its journey back to Earth, with NASA closely monitoring the situation. The spacecraft is expected to land safely at White Sands Space Harbor in New Mexico. NASA will offer live coverage of the Starliner's return, available on NASA+, the NASA app, YouTube, and the agency's official website.
latest news.title: NASA astronauts awaits 2025 SpaceX ride home: Starliner to return to Earth without Sunita Williams; here's how to watch

latest news.eng_title: Boeing Starliner set to return to earth on September 6 without astronauts onboard
latest news.summary: Boeing's Starliner spacecraft, which was launched on June 5, 2024, carrying astronauts Sunita Williams and Butch Wilmore, is set to return to Earth on September 6 without any passengers. The spacecraft was initially intended to bring Sunita and Butch back to Earth, but due to a helium leak and malfunctioning thrusters, it was decided to land the Starliner back on Earth without any crew. The spacecraft has been docked at the International Space Station for three months. Sunita and Butch's return journey has been postponed to February 2025, and they will be brought back to Earth by SpaceX's Dragon spacecraft. The Starliner will land on Earth six hours after undocking from the ISS at White Sands Space Harbor in New Mexico.
latest news.title: Boeing Starliner set to return to earth on September 6 without astronauts onboard

latest news.eng_title: NASA Explains Strange Noises on Boeing Starliner Spacecraft
latest news.summary: NASA's Associate Administrator for Communications, Cheryl Warner, explained that the strange noise heard by astronaut Barry 'Willmore on the Boeing Starliner spacecraft was caused by the specific audio system of the International Space Station (ISS). According to Warner, the ISS audio system can connect 'multiple devices and modules,' resulting in background noise. The Boeing Starliner spacecraft, docked to the ISS, began making unusual sounds on September 2. As previously announced, the spacecraft is scheduled to undock from the ISS on September 6 and return to Earth the following day. NASA astronauts will return to Earth on the Crew Dragon spacecraft in February 2025.
latest news.title: В НАСА назвали причину странных звуков на Boeing Starliner

latest news.eng_title: Nasa explains strange noise heard by astronaut in Boeing's Starliner
latest news.summary: Nasa has explained the strange noise heard by astronaut Butch Wilmore in Boeing's Starliner spacecraft as feedback from the speaker due to an audio configuration issue between the spacecraft and the International Space Station. According to Nasa, the crew is asked to contact mission control when they hear sounds originating in the comm system. The agency confirmed that the feedback has no technical impact on the crew, Starliner, or station operations. The Starliner is currently docked to the ISS and is scheduled to undock on September 6. Nasa astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams will remain on the ISS until February 2025 as part of the SpaceX Crew-9 mission. Meanwhile, Boeing's Starliner is targeting a landing on September 7 after a six-hour flight back to Earth, following which it will be shipped back to Boeing's factory for further analysis.
latest news.title: Nasa explains strange noise heard by astronaut in Boeing's Starliner

news knowledge.eng_title: Starliner to Return to Earth Without Crew, Astronauts to Return in 2025
news knowledge.summary: The NASA and Boeing have scheduled the Starliner spacecraft to undock from the International Space Station on September 6 without its crew. The Starliner successfully completed an uncrewed orbital flight test with a successful entry and landing on two separate occasions. After undocking, the Starliner will take approximately six hours to reach the landing site at the White Sands Space Harbor in New Mexico, where it will land with parachutes and airbags to cushion the impact. The spacecraft will then be secured and prepared for its return to the Boeing Starliner factory at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida. Astronauts Suni Williams and Butch Wilmore will remain on the space station as part of the Expedition 71/72 crew until February 2025, when they will return with the Crew-9 mission.
news knowledge.title: Starliner regresará a la Tierra sin tripulación; Astronautas regresarán hasta 2025

news knowledge.eng_title: NASA to Bring Starliner Back to Earth on September 6
news knowledge.summary: NASA announced on Friday (29) that the Boeing's Starliner capsule is expected to leave the International Space Station on September 6, provided that the weather conditions are suitable for the return to Earth. The date was revealed after an analysis conducted by NASA and Boeing. If everything goes well, the spacecraft will be undocked from the ISS at 19h04 Brasília time. It will travel back and is expected to land at the White Sands spaceport in New Mexico after six hours. The location was one of the main training areas for the astronauts of the space shuttle. In a statement, NASA officials explained that the Starliner will return to Earth autonomously and without a crew. 'The ground teams can remotely control the spacecraft if necessary during the necessary maneuvers for safe undocking, re-entry, and landing with the help of parachutes in the southeastern United States,' they added. This is not the first time the Starliner has returned to Earth autonomously. It happened during the uncrewed flight tests in 2019 and 2022 - in the first one, the spacecraft did not reach the ISS, but in the second, it did. The Starliner was launched to the ISS on June 5, carrying astronauts Suni Williams and Butch Wilmore to the orbital laboratory. The spacecraft was docked to the station the next day, but suffered helium leaks and failures in five of its 28 thrusters. Since then, NASA and Boeing have extended the stay of the duo on the ISS while analyzing the incident, and concluded that it was too dangerous to use the Starliner to bring them back to Earth. Therefore, they will remain in the laboratory until February 2025, and then will return in a Crew Dragon capsule from SpaceX.
news knowledge.title: NASA decide trazer nave Starliner de volta à Terra em 6 de setembro

news knowledge.eng_title: ‘Uncrewed' NASA Boeing Starliner ‘Calypso' to undock at International Space Station on September 6. When, where to watch
news knowledge.summary: The uncrewed NASA Boeing Starliner 'Calypso' is set to undock from the International Space Station on September 6. The spacecraft will then return to Earth, landing at White Sands Space Harbor in New Mexico after a six-hour journey. NASA has confirmed that the Starliner has successfully completed two orbital flight tests, including a previous uncrewed entry and landing. The return can be watched live on the Space Affairs' YouTube channel. The spacecraft will touch down at 9:30 AM IST on September 7, descending under parachutes and with inflated airbags to cushion the impact. This comes after NASA announced that astronauts Barry Wilmore and Sunita Williams will return to Earth in a SpaceX vehicle in February next year, due to issues with the Starliner's propulsion system.
news knowledge.title: ‘Uncrewed' NASA Boeing Starliner ‘Calypso' to undock at International Space Station on September 6. When, where to watch

news knowledge.eng_title: Boeing's Uncrewed Starliner Capsule Could Return After Sep 6, Says NASA
news knowledge.summary: NASA has decided to proceed with the undocking of the uncrewed Boeing Starliner capsule not before September 6, after reviewing the spacecraft's propulsion system issues. The Starliner experienced glitches within the first 24 hours of its flight to the International Space Station (ISS) in June, which were deemed too risky for a crewed return. The journey back to Earth is expected to take approximately six hours, and ground teams will remotely guide the spacecraft through necessary manoeuvres for a safe undocking, re-entry and parachute-assisted landing in the southwestern United States. NASA astronauts who flew to the ISS in the Starliner will return to Earth in a SpaceX vehicle early next year. 'The Starliner has previously completed a successful uncrewed entry and landing during two orbital flight tests,' NASA said. The agency is confident in the spacecraft's ability to safely return to Earth, and the undocking is expected to take place not before September 6.
news knowledge.title: Boeing's Uncrewed Starliner Capsule Could Return After Sep 6, Says NASA

news knowledge.eng_title: Boeing's uncrewed Starliner set to undock after Sept 6, NASA says
news knowledge.summary: NASA has announced that the uncrewed Boeing Starliner capsule will undock from the International Space Station not before September 6, 2024, after a review concluded. The decision comes after propulsion system issues were deemed too risky for a crewed return, following a series of glitches within the first 24 hours of the capsule's flight to the ISS. The Starliner's journey back to Earth is expected to take approximately six hours from undocking to landing at White Sands Space Harbor in New Mexico, according to NASA.
news knowledge.title: Boeing's uncrewed Starliner set to undock after Sept 6, NASA says

news knowledge.eng_title: Boeing Starliner To Undock From ISS And Return To Earth Without Crew As Early As Sept. 6
news knowledge.summary: Boeing's Starliner spacecraft will return to Earth without crew as early as September 6, according to NASA. The spacecraft, which launched into space with two astronauts on June 5, will undock from the International Space Station at 6:04 p.m. EDT on September 6 and land at White Sands Space Harbor in New Mexico at 12:03 a.m. on September 7. The spacecraft will then be returned to Boeing's factory at NASA's Kennedy Space Center in Florida. NASA announced earlier this month that the astronauts, Sunita Williams and Butch Wilmore, would return via a SpaceX vehicle in February due to technical issues with the Starliner spacecraft. 'The return in September is expected to be safe and uneventful,' said NASA, as the spacecraft has previously completed a successful uncrewed entry and landing as part of its previous flight tests.
news knowledge.title: Boeing Starliner To Undock From ISS And Return To Earth Without Crew As Early As Sept. 6

news knowledge.eng_title: Boeing Starliner to Depart ISS on September 6
news knowledge.summary: The Boeing Starliner spacecraft, uncrewed, will depart the International Space Station (ISS) on September 6, according to NASA. 'NASA and Boeing have agreed to undock the Starliner spacecraft from the ISS no earlier than 18:04 Eastern European Time (19:04 Moscow Time) on Friday, September 6, pending readiness for operation,' the statement reads. After undocking, the Starliner will take approximately six hours to reach the landing zone in New Mexico, and is expected to land around 12:03 (13:03 Moscow Time) on September 7. NASA Administrator Bill Nelson stated, 'Spaceflight is inherently risky, even in the safest and most routine of regimes.' Astronauts Butch Wilmore and Sunita Williams will remain on the ISS until February 2025, and will return to Earth on the SpaceX Dragon spacecraft with two other crew members. In June, Boeing conducted its first crewed launch of the CST-100 Starliner to the ISS, with the goal of testing the spacecraft's ability to transport crews to and from the station.
news knowledge.title: Starliner без экипажа покинет МКС 6 сентября

news knowledge.eng_title: NASA: Boeing's uncrewed Starliner set to undock after Sept. 6
news knowledge.summary: According to NASA, the Boeing Starliner capsule is set to undock on September 6th without a crew, after issues with its propulsion system were detected during its flight to the International Space Station. The two astronauts who flew in the Starliner to the ISS in June were initially meant to return after 10 days, but their stay was extended due to the Starliner's issues. NASA says the uncrewed return is expected to take about six hours, with ground teams guiding the spacecraft through undocking, re-entry, and landing at White Sands Space Harbor in New Mexico. This comes as the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration grounded SpaceX's Falcon 9 rocket on Wednesday, following a failure of a routine landing attempt during a Starlink mission, which may also delay SpaceX's Polaris Dawn mission.
news knowledge.title: NASA: Boeing's uncrewed Starliner set to undock after Sept. 6

news knowledge.eng_title: Boeing's uncrewed Starliner capsule could return by late next week: Nasa
news knowledge.summary: Nasa will proceed with the undocking of the uncrewed Boeing Starliner capsule not before September 6, after concluding a review. The space agency deemed the propulsion system issues too risky for a crewed return, following a series of glitches within the first 24 hours of its flight to the ISS. The journey back to Earth is expected to take approximately six hours, with ground teams remotely guiding the spacecraft through necessary manoeuvres for a safe undocking, re-entry and parachute-assisted landing in southwestern United States. As stated by Nasa, 'Starliner has previously completed a successful uncrewed entry and landing during two orbital flight tests.'
news knowledge.title: Boeing's uncrewed Starliner capsule could return by late next week: Nasa

news knowledge.eng_title: Boeing Starliner: Decision on Return Expected by End of Month
news knowledge.summary: The NASA is evaluating all options to ensure a safe return of the two astronauts, Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams, who arrived on the International Space Station (ISS) aboard the Boeing Starliner. The decision on whether to return with the Starliner or the Crew Dragon is expected by the end of the month. According to Eric Berger of Ars Technica, the planned undocking with crew is scheduled for September 2, while the undocking without crew is expected on September 6. If the latter occurs, the flight software will need to be updated to perform all procedures without manual intervention. The analysis of the data from the tests conducted on one of the available engines at the White Sands Test Facility in New Mexico is ongoing. Engineers are still trying to understand why a Teflon gasket on a valve is inflating, reducing the flow of propellant to the reaction control system, which is essential for undocking and deorbiting operations.
news knowledge.title: Boeing Starliner: decisione sul rientro a fine mese
